subsubsection.title: Definitions
subsubsection.p:
Write a definition or description for each term. You can find answers in Section 1.2 of your textbook.
Function
Input variable
Output variable
Function value
Function notation

statement.p: Identify each term above, or give an example, for this situation: At time t seconds, the height of a basketball above the ground, h, in feet, is given by ~~h=-16t^2+20t+5.

ol.li: h is a function of t.
The function value for t=1 is h=9.

statement.p:
Simplify each expression.
x^2(x^2)^3
(2t^2)^4
\dfrac{5^6}{5^2}
(-h)^3-h^3

Each "simplification" is INCORRECT. Write a correct version.
(3+b^3)^2 \rightarrow 9+b^6
5a^3+3a^2 \rightarrow 8a^5
(4x^4)^2 \rightarrow 16x^{16}
\dfrac{w^3}{w^9} \rightarrow -w^3

introduction.p: To solve simple non-linear equations, we "undo" the operation performed on the variable.

statement.p: Solve the equation ~~5 \sqrt{t} = 83
Solve the equation ~~\dfrac{15}{y}=45
Solve the equation ~~\dfrac{4.8}{w}=3
Solve the equation ~~18=36\sqrt{q}

introduction.p: We can use function notation to describe a graph.

Fill in the blanks:
The point (a,b) lies on the graph of f if and only if .
Each point on the graph of y=f(x) has coordinates .
A graph of a function is increasing if the values get larger as we read from left to right.
The maximum value of a function is the of the highest point on the graph.

statement.p: How do you know that the point (1,9) lies on the graph of f(t)=-16t^2+20t+5 ?
What are the coordinates of any point on the graph of h=f(t) ?

introduction.p: Every point on the graph of an equation y=f(x) tells us the solution of the equation for a particular value of y.

statement.p: Use the graph of y=\dfrac{-2}{3}x-4 to solve the equation \dfrac{-2}{3}x-4=-2.

stack.p: We see that y has been replaced by -2 in the equation for the graph. So we look for the point on the graph that has y-coordinate -2.
This point, labeled P on the graph at right, has x-coordinate -3. Because it lies on the graph, the point P(-3,-2) is a solution of the equation y=\dfrac{-2}{3}x-4.

solution.p: But this statement also tells us that -3 is a solution of the equation \dfrac{-2}{3}x-4=2. You can check that substituting x=-3 into this equation produces a true statement.

statement.p: Use the graph of y=\dfrac{-2}{3}x-4 to solve the inequality \dfrac{-2}{3}x-4 \le -2.

stack.p: We would like to find the x-coordinates of all points on the graph that have y-coordinate less than or equal to -2. These points on the graph are indicated by the heavy portion of the line.
The x-coordinates of these points are shown by the heavy portion of the x-axis. The solution is x \ge -3, or in interval notation, [-3,\infty) .

statement.p:
Use the graph to solve the equation or inequality. (Note the scales on the axes.) Show your solutions on the graph. Then verify your solutions by solving algebraically.
-9-\dfrac{x}{4}=-2
-9-\dfrac{x}{4} \ge -5

Use the graph to solve the equation or inequality. (Note the scales on the axes.) Show your solutions on the graph. Then verify your solutions by solving algebraically.
7-\dfrac{2x}{3}=3
7-\dfrac{2x}{3} \lt -1

introduction.p: The volume of a box is measured in cubic units and can be calculated using the formula V=lwh, where l,~w, and h stand for the length, width, and height of the box. Volume measures the amount of space inside an object by telling us how many blocks 1 unit on a side will fit inside the space. For example, the volume of the box below, whose dimensions are given in centimeters, is

It may seem difficult to measure the inside of a round object like a sphere or a cone in cubic units, but you can imagine filling the object with liquid and then pouring the liquid into a box to measure its volume.

statement.p: An aquarium is 24 inches long and 10 inches wide. What is the area of its base? How much water is needed to fill it to a depth of 5 inches?

solution.p: The area of the base is A=lw=(24~ \text{in})(10~ \text{in})=240~ \text{in}^2 To calculate the volume of water, we can multiply the area of the base, lw, by the height of the water, h. V=(lw)h=Ah=(240~ \text{in}^2)(5~ \text{in})=1200~ \text{in}^3

statement.p: The diameter of a spherical wax candle is 5 inches. What is the volume of wax in the candle?

solution.p: The radius of the candle is half its diameter, or 2.5 inches. The volume of the candle is V=\dfrac{4}{3}\pi r^3=\dfrac{4}{3}\pi(2.5~ \text{in})^3=65.45~\text{in}^3

statement.p: Find the volume of a cylindrical water tank whose diameter is 20 feet and whose height is 20 feet.
The diameter of the Earth is about 7920 miles. Find its volume.

introduction.p: Be careful when simplifying radicals after extracting roots. Recall the properties of radicals reviewed in Section 4.4.

statement.p:
Can you simplify the first expression into the second expression? (Decide whether the expressions are equivalent.)
Is ~~\sqrt{4+x^2}~~ equivalent to ~~2+x?
Is ~~\sqrt{\dfrac{x^2}{9}}~~ equivalent to ~~\dfrac{x}{3}~~ for ~x \ge 0?
Is ~~\sqrt{w-3}~~ equivalent to ~~\sqrt{w} - \sqrt{3}?

li.p: If the expressions are equivalent, they must be equal for every value of the variable. Let's test with x=3. Then \sqrt{4+x^2} \amp = \sqrt{4+9} = \sqrt{13} \approx 3.6 \text{but}~~~~~~~~~ 2+x \amp = 2+3 = 5 No, the expressions are not equivalent.

Because \left(\dfrac{x}{3}\right)^2 = \dfrac{x}{3} \cdot \dfrac{x}{3} = \dfrac{x^2}{3^2} = \dfrac{x^2}{9}, it is also true that \sqrt{\dfrac{x^2}{9}} = \dfrac{x}{3}. Yes, the expressions are equivalent.
Let w=16. Then \sqrt{w-3} \amp = \sqrt{16-3} = \sqrt{13} \approx 3.6 \text{but}~~~ \sqrt{w}-\sqrt{3} \amp = \sqrt{16}-\sqrt{3} \approx 4-1.7 = 2.3 No, the expressions are not equivalent.

introduction.p: Decide whether the expressions are equivalent. Assume all variables are positive.

statement.p: \sqrt{b^2-81}~ and ~b-9
\sqrt{64x^2y^2}~ and ~8xy
\sqrt{64+x^2y^2}~ and ~8+xy
\sqrt{\dfrac{c^2+d^2}{4b^2}}~ and ~\dfrac{\sqrt{c^2+d^2}}{2b}
